awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Genome-wide Analysis of Pathogen-induced Endogenous siRNAs in Plant Defense Responses in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration: RNA silencing, mediated by small interfering RNAs (siRNAs), has evolved as an antiviral defense mechanism in plants and animals. However, it is not known whether host cells also utilize siRNAs in antibacterial and antifungal defenses. Thousands of endogenous siRNAs have been discovered by deep sequencing recently, but their important function in gene regulation has just started to be unveiled. This project will identify endogenous siRNAs that are induced by bacterial and fungal pathogens on a genome-wide scale and characterize the biogenesis and mode of action of a subset of the siRNAs. Furthermore, the physiological functions of these siRNAs and their target genes in plant defense responses will be examined. This project explores a previously uncharted area in plant defense responses. This work will likely reveal new regulatory mechanisms underlying plant disease resistance and defense responses and ultimately contribute to the development of new strategies to combat plant pathogens to improve agriculture. As an important component of this project, an innovative summer course with a follow-up training program is designed for undergraduate students from UC Riverside (UCR) and a local Hispanic Serving Institution San Bernardino Valley College. This summer course will cover basic concepts and provide hands-on experience in the area of Plant Molecular Biology and siRNA-Mediated Gene Silencing. A follow-up training program will be provided to those students who have interest in research. This program will mainly target women and minority students who have no or limited access to research opportunities, with the aim of enhancing their chance of pursuing advanced education and a scientific career in the future.

por.por_cntn:
Small RNAs are short, non-coding regulatory RNA molecules that regulate development and growth, responses to biotic and abiotic stresses, and genome integrity in many eukaryotic organisms. Emerging evidence suggests that small RNAs play an important role in regulating plant host-pathogen interactions. This project aimed to identify the small RNAs that are induced by bacterial and fungal pathogen infections on a genome-wide scale. We have also addressed the following questions about these pathogen-regulated small RNAs: Where are they generated from? How are they made? How do they function? What do they target?

 

Using high throughput sequencing, we have identified a group of pathogen-regulated host endogenous small RNAs (including many new miRNAs and siRNAs). The bacterial pathogen we used for this study was Pseudomonas syringae, which infects a wide variety of fruits, vegetables and ornamental plants. The fungal pathogens we used were Botrytis cinerea, which causes grey mold disease on almost all fruits and vegetables, and Alternaria brassicicola, which causes dark leaf spot disease on most Brassica species. We found that some of these pathogen-induced small RNAs target and silence negative regulators of plant defense signaling and rapidly turn on plant immune responses during infection. A group of miRNAs coordinately regulates and fine-tunes multiple plant hormone pathways and contributes to host innate immunity. We have discovered several new classes of functional small RNAs, including long small interfering RNAs (lsiRNAs), miRNA-like sRNAs (milRNAs), miRNA gene-derived siRNAs, and a functional miRNA*. We have also performed genome-wide analysis on siRNAs that are generated from natural antisense transcripts.

 

In addition, we also found that Arabidopsis RNA silencing pathway component Argonaute 2 (AGO2) is highly induced by the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato and positively regulates antibacterial immunity. Sequencing profiling of AGO2-associated small RNAs revealed a significant enrichment of several miRNA*s. One such abundant species is miR393*, which targets a Golgi-localized SNARE gene MEMB12. miR393*-mediated MEMB12 silencing leads to increased secretion of antimicrobial peptide PR1 and confers resistance. Since miR393 is also known to contribute to antibacterial immunity by suppressing auxin receptors, miR393*/miR393 represent a novel example of a miRNA*/miRNA pair that functions in host immunity through two distinct AGOs—miR393* through AGO2 and miR393 through AGO1.

 

During this funding period, we published a total of 27 publications, including 15 research articles, 7 review papers, and 5 book chapters. I also edited one book.

 

This project also provided excellent research and training opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and even high school students. During the entire funding period, a total of 4 postdoctoral fellows, 3 graduate students, 12 undergraduate students, and 3 high school students were trained in my lab. For the undergraduate students and high school students, doing hands-on research in a lab is an eye-opening experience that attracts them to be engaged in and/or pursuit a career in biological science.  The undergraduate students have learned not only the basic plant molecular biology techniques in the lab, but they also learned how to interpret the results and how to solve problems. Four of them worked in the lab for more than 2 years and made considerable a contribution to the projects, eventually earning them co-authorship in 3 of our lab’s research publications.
